headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Awaiting Biden's Speech & Jokes At WH Correspondents' Dinner; Comedian Darrell Hammond On Hosting WH Correspondents' Dinner; Soon: Biden, Comedian Roy Wood Jr. Roast Washington & Media. Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: JESSICA DEAN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Tonight, a celebration of the First Amendment and the importance of a free press in the United States.

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Also, jokes, lots of jokes, all the most powerful people in Washington, except us, all in the same room and about to be roasted by the President and a comedian. The White House Correspondents' Dinner starts now.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) GEORGE W. BUSH, 43RD U.S. PRESIDENT: Members of the White House Correspondents' Association, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Here I am.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A time-honored tradition, bringing together Washington's most powerful people.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) RONALD REAGAN, 40TH U.S. PRESIDENT: I'm so desperate for attention, I almost considered holding a news conference. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And powerful laughs.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) BARACK OBAMA, 44TH U.S. PRESIDENT: I invited Luther, my anger translator, to join me here tonight. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tonight, comedian Roy Wood Jr. takes aim at the politicians, and President Biden himself will get in on the foot, --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: I told my grandkids and Pete Buttigieg, they could stay up late and watch this show tonight.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- from roasts --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump has been saying that he will run for President as a Republican. So, I just assumed he was running as a joke.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- to jokes --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Reality has a well-known liberal bias.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: -- to mic drops --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: Obama.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And every row in between.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) BILL CLINTON, 42ND U.S. PRESIDENT: Yes. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What will happen this year? The White House Correspondents' Dinner on CNN starts now.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: It is only one night a year, and this is that night. The annual White House Correspondents' Dinner are underway right here in Washington D.C.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: You let up the hanger stockings up on the mantel right now. It's that kind of night. This is the hour when we will hear the jokes from comedian Roy Wood Jr., also President Biden. There are going to be some serious important moments too, as the night is about honoring freedom of the press.We want to kick off this hour, though, with some very special guests with our very special red carpet king Harry Enten. And he is joined, I'm told, by Sara Sidner and Kate Bolduan. All true?

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: And this is 100 percent true, but we even have two additional guests. It feels like the line just keeps growing here. We have Sara to my left. We have Kate over here.

utterances.speaker: KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR, CNN NEWS CENTRAL
utterances.sentences: We have Rena -- can I say.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, you can.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: May I jump in?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: You may jump in.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Kate Bolduan, thank you so much. Lena Headey and Marc Menchaca.MARC MENCHACA, ACTOR, "OZARK": Menchaca lot here.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We have been joking with them all. They're sitting in a table, and we have been boozled them to come up to hang out with us.LENA HEADEY, MARC MENCHACA'S WIFE: It was a total bamboozle, by the way.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: We told them there was free food.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: No free showed.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: And then we showed up it was only Harry Enten.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: So, have you ever -- if you guys ever been to one of these before?

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: No. We have not. And when, we got the invite via Lena, she was like we shouldn't go there, and I said, no, we're absolutely going. Well, no.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: So, it's your fault, is what we've been informed.

utterances.speaker: HEADEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR, CNN NEWS CENTRAL
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, I know a couple of things because we haven't -- you just met somebody, don't be upset, he does not work for a network, but you just met someone who you thought you would never meet in life.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Never in my life.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: What was that moment like for you?

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Well, who was it, first and foremost?

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: He gave me a smile that's as big as on my face right now.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You were kind of fame like.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: I was a little bit -- total federal.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Yeah (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: So, you never thought --

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Never thought -- never thought -- no. I never entertained the thought in my mind.BOLDUAN It's actually -- it's a perfect encapsulation of what this evening offers up, which is just like a collision of worlds, sometimes strange, like now, but sometimes really amazing, like now. It's like everyone coming together in like a kind of a wacky fashion. I reject the word nerd prom because some of us don't even deserve to be in the categories of nerds, because I'm not grown up to actually be a nerd.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I am not smart enough to be a nerd, but you are.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You are welcome. We love nerds.

utterances.speaker: HEADEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, well, I think we go through a lot of red carpets.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Always embarrassing on tough floors.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Do you like a red carpet?

utterances.speaker: HEADEY
utterances.sentences: Love, enough of them.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I think the only thing -- the thing I am worried about is she only speaks in sarcasm.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Yeah. No.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: We relish the opportunity to get on that. Yeah. I like to get on that x that they say and then stand there as long as I can.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: And until uncomfortable, they finally say, can you please get off? Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, sir, we need the carpet now.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: They call me Ms. Sidner, and I told them to knock it off.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Wow. That was aggressive.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Well, tonight, --

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: -- they -- we went out there. And then, they were saying something I couldn't understand. And I realized they were saying, can we just get a picture of Lena, and I said, yep. And I backed up.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: Now, you know how every journalist feels is told to walk a red carpet when celebrities are on it. Like, it's a terrifying anxiety inducing experience. But, we're having a great time.

utterances.speaker: HEADEY
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. You guys have made the night, we tell you.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you, and you made our nights, and now I want to toss it back to one of my favorite celebrities, John Berman.

utterances.speaker: BOLDUAN
utterances.sentences: John.

utterances.speaker: MENCHACA
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it. Love you but not as much as Al Sharpton.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: You have four seconds.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I will take it.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I will take what I can get. Thank you all for that. All of you have a wonderful evening. I'll see Kate and Sara on Monday, and we're going to talk about this, believe me. But, I -- there was Queen Cersei.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Queen Cersei was there.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: And I think Kate made such a great point which is, it is such a kind of smashing together of all these different worlds you have, media. You have politics. You have celebrity and Hollywood, and it all kind of mushes together in Washington D.C., which does have the feel of a small town from time to time. I don't know if any of you all have been in the room and been -- I assume you all have. But, what are kind of your thoughts about it in terms of how it mixes together all these different people?ASHLEY ALLISON, FORMER NATIONAL COALITIONS DIRECTOR FOR BIDEN-HARRIS 2020: Well, I remember last year, I saw Pat Sajak and I lost it. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: I mean, I like lost it. And it's like, what are you doing in D.C.? Why aren't you like, with Vanna, flipping letters? But, it is a really interesting night. There are so many parties. It's so much fun. You get to see people you haven't seen in a really long time, and you get to see people that you've never really worked with, and get to ask them, like, why are you here, and you realize it's because they care about this country. And it's not just a night of celebrity and fun and jokes. It's actually like people come to D.C. A lot of them go on the Hill. A lot on the go to the White House, doing some lobbying on policy issues. So, it's a really cool weekend in the city.

utterances.speaker: LZ GRANDERSON, OPED COLUMNIST, LOS ANGELES TIMES
utterances.sentences: I remember when I was there during Obama's last White House Correspondents' Dinner. And to your point, I was star truck by the cast of scandal.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Yeah. All right, everybody. I remember --

utterances.speaker: GRANDERSON
utterances.sentences: And it was so funny -- DEAN(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: GRANDERSON
utterances.sentences: So, my first see was actually very close to the castle scandal, suddenly there was, like, a girl. What's going to happen next? This one comes to me and say, I'm sorry, but your seat is actually down. It was actually close to the front stage. And I initially didn't want to go back because I was like, girl scandals over here. I don't know what's up there, but scandals right here.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: And it is funny how, like, the politicians or the media wants to meet Hollywood. Hollywood will want to meet, like -- as we were just hearing from him, he is, like, I got to meet Al Sharpton. Like, everybody kind of gets weirdly star struck by kind of -- it's surprising kind of mix there, I think. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: I mean, in fact, Joe was at the White House on Thursday. I saw him on West Exec. And I was like, I was literally like, what's the culture doing at the White House? It was literally fat Joe, the vice president, they met. He was here advocating on transparency and healthcare and making healthcare affordable. You don't think those two worlds collide, but this weekend, it lets it happen.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: All right, Scott. Who was the -- who made you star struck?

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Who are you most excited to meet?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT JENNINGS, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: I think the last time I went to this in the Bush years, it was the Stephen Colbert. I think he was the headliner. And I did meet him that night.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: And I can see he made a big impression.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: You are still giddy over it now.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I mean, there were other celebrities there. I've seem to recall, sort of recognizing. I mean, this is not my --

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: You don't do even fun.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I'm not the --

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: You are not a pop cultured guy.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: If you were in The Avengers, I know who you are.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: If you're on any -- there is some children's programming --

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: -- that I'm generally aware of. Other than that --

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: So, I got time for --

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, I will say that was Queen Cersei right there. And it does -- I wanted to ask her, so many things are compared to Game of Thrones. Oh, it's just like Game of Thrones. I'm like, well, is this going to be like Game of Thrones? What actually is like Game of Thrones?

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: What could possibly go wrong --

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Sounds great.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: -- for comedian Roy Wood Jr. There he is. You can sight him right there. There Senator Chris Van Hollen of Maryland. But, Roy Wood Jr. will be up on stage this hour, delivering his comedic take on the year that has been in politics and the press, and of course, no doubt he will roast the President who will be sitting right there next to him. Our next guest has done that several times.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That was comedian Darrell Hammond, and he is here with us now. Thank you so much for being with us. It's such an honor to see you here. And I have to say, you're one of the few people who knows what it's like to be up on that stage. What is it like to be standing next to the President of the United States and making fun of him?

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: I think it's really -- the whole thing feels so natural, because the whole room has more power in it than any room you've ever been in before, and that includes Joint Chiefs, members of Congress. And then, there is the President and there is the First Lady. And it's like a -- what do you call it, a high wire act, it feels like to me, and there is a potential for lots of destruction to your career if you bomb. It's a tough crowd. It was tough for me. I was always a little bit scared.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, man, I would be terrified. I think it's --

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: -- it's a tough crowd. That crowd doesn't always take jokes at their own expense very well. So, that can tough. We heard from Roy just a little bit ago, and he had all the cards. He is trying to figure out which jokes he is using, which ones he is not. Do -- when you did it, did you really nail it down, or did you do anything on the fly?

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: I had planned a, b, c and d on the day. It's in front of me too. Yeah. I mean, listen, if you start off and the first couple of minutes is not going well, you got to veer off and try another direction, like, to me, obligating yourself to what you're going to do out there. At least in my case, it would have been treacherous.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Do you have any moments that have scarred you for life?

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: I'm not scarred for life. I -- there was one time I said something, I sort of lamely said, and I think that women should be in positions of power in the Military. And you could feel the room just go shake, just dead stop. And this whole August (ph) crowd is looking at you, like, we're not helping you. We're not helping you. And we're not going to laugh, because they don't want to laugh at something or applaud at something that some of their political friends might find objectionable. It gets all bipartisan on you. You're like, wow, man, I just stepped in the wrong direction for one second.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: But, I kept going.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: You've to live to tell the tale.

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And then I told -- I made another mistake. I called Bill Clinton, Bill, and more shock and awe in the audience said, what the hell. It is wrong with you. And then I had to correct that. So, I survived okay, but it was scary. And there were definitely some rough patches in the stuff that I did.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. We were talking earlier tonight about just how much has changed just in the environment since when you probably hosted. Now, you've got social media, and how so many people probably watch this. There'll be clips. Maybe in the past, you could do it, and it might be hard to find again the next day if it didn't go so well. But, it seems like it's even more pressure now, because it could live on forever on the internet.

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: Forever and forever and forever. The whole world knows real quick, like, everywhere you look, you can see examples of your failures and successes.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's -- that is quite a group, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: It is, and they're all --

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: -- wearing the same thing. I mean, do you think any of the men are looking at each other saying, oh my god, I'm so embarrassed. He is wearing just what I am.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Big laugh from the comedian.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That was a courtesy. That was a courtesy laugh right there.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Darrell, that was nice. That was believable.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Okay.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I believed it was genuine.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: That was pity. Is there any error here, do you think, is particularly ripe this year? If you were doing this tonight, what are some of the things that you might make fun of?

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: I don't think it's ripe. I mean, it's -- I think it's dangerous. You're going to do some AI. You're going to talk about Ted Cruz, the audio tapes. I mean, you're going to talk about mental competency tests. I mean, where you going to go out there? You want to try to stay down in the middle. It's like the closer you get to something that someone will be disgusted by, and they can all get all bipartisan and sort of do a Judge Judy on you. The closer you get to that, the funnier you are. You just occasionally step over the line and that's a crowd to let you know up pretty fast.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: How hard do you think you could go, or how hard did you feel you could go on the President, and how hard do you think that Roy Wood thinks he can do it tonight?

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: And then, just, like that. It is. You're right. It's a high wire act, for sure. But, we are --

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: -- we are cheering on Roy Wood. We're excited to see what he has got tonight, and it is fun to walk down memory lane with you.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: Darrell Hammond, thank you so much. Great to see you.

utterances.speaker: HAMMOND
utterances.sentences: My pleasure. Nice to see you both.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We are going to be back with much more of our special coverage, including comedian Roy Wood Jr. and President Joe Biden. Stay with us.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I have one question for you. Obviously, you're the comedian of the evening. But, if you were not in fact the comedian of the evening, would you actually be watching this event?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're the dad.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I am the dada (ph) guy. You know who I am?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I know exactly.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: And I know who you are.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: But, this was going up against Monday Night Football. And I'll be the yard and check back on it later.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: That's a great question. I have no idea what I'm doing here. Oh, they called this the nerd prom. I have to ask, how does this compare to your actual prom back in the day? Well, actually, there is no difference between this prom, my actual prom. I don't have a date to either one.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well, I wasn't nerd. So, this feels right to me.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Your accent makes my accent look so crummy by comparison, and people always say I have this thick New York accent, but nothing compared to your accent.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Wow. Who can make this up?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Who can -- I don't think anyone could make it up. Oh, look, there is Phil Mattingly. I wonder if he'll tell us tales from his baseball days.

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: You know what I would love to see do this event? Chris Rock.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Oh. That -- wasn't here be okay?

utterances.speaker: ROY
utterances.sentences: You said it, not me.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I am very hard of myself. Do you suggest that he gets for dinner if he is looking for something interesting to eat in Bentonville, Arkansas?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, of course. The barbecue can't be beat there.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: You stand then. You stand now. When the heck do you ever sit down, I'll start on this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's sort of a foodie paradise there. So, you'll find a lot of different options, and some incredible tacos, Mexican food.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I'm Harry.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Harry, I am Tim.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I know you, because I watched the show Wings. Wings was one of my favorite shows of all time.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You must have been four-years-old. But, great. I'm glad you watched it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I was on an episode of Wings.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Were you really?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I played this tall girl at a single stance, and I started crying because I'm too tall and no one wants to dance with me.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: You are not too tall for me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Never.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tell three of us wear heels, actually. That's the -- that's a little known secret of this team.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Whatever you want to wear is all right by me. Can you believe they allowed me to do this? And I'm just standing here. I go out of myself. Who am I and what am I doing here? I don't really know the answer to that question. But, someone thought it wise for me to come down here. So, I was like, sure, what the heck? I'll interview some people. It turns out I've met some people. I've had a few laughs, a few jokes. But at the end of the day, Washington won't change me. I'll change Washington.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I mean, I wish he'd have fun.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: We have no idea what just happened right there.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't this the Asa Hutchinson has any idea what happened right now.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: No. He was like, excuse me.

utterances.speaker: BERMAN
utterances.sentences: My prom.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I was told I would not be asked about my prom.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: There is something before, like --

utterances.speaker: DANNY DEVITO, AMERICAN ACTOR
utterances.sentences: Gimme some more of that cracker. Yeah, I come over here. I'm going to get bit by a horse. Okay, all-righty. Okay, that's the finger.

utterances.speaker: SCHWARZENEGGER
utterances.sentences: Good girl. Good girl.

utterances.speaker: DEVITO
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: SCHWARZENEGGER
utterances.sentences: Now, speaking of questions that annoyed the hell out of me, I would like to introduce you to someone who covered me during my time as governor of the great State of California, who has gone on to bigger and better things. Please welcome White House Correspondents' Association's President, Tamara Keith.TAMARA KEITH, NPR WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT AND CO-HOST: Ally of the people has a nice ring to it. Thank you, Governor, and welcome to the White House Correspondents' Association Dinner. For the first time since 2016, we have both the President and the Vice President here, as well as their spouses. Their presence is a statement and endorsement of the importance of a free and independent press, even if they don't always like the questions we ask or the way we ask them. Now, acknowledging that this is an entire evening dedicated to celebrating journalism and the White House press corps, I am also here to tell you that it isn't about us or the celebrities who are here, though, thank you for your support. Thank you very much for your support. As the governor said, as weird as this event is with politicians and glamorous famous people and totally unglamorous journalists all gathered in the same room, there is something uniquely American about the fact that we can all be here together. And then, these reporters can go out on Monday and do stories about these very same politicians that pull no punches. When we're asking questions in the Oval Office under the wing of Air Force One or in the briefing room, we are standing for the American people. Our responsibility to the country is woven into the fabric of the nation, enshrined in the First Amendment of the Constitution. And we take that responsibility seriously. But, not so seriously that we can't have a little fun tonight and laugh at a few jokes, including some at our own expense. So, welcome to the nation's biggest celebration of the First Amendment and the important work of bringing an inquisitive spotlight to those in power. Up first to present the WHCA awards, please welcome ABC News White House Correspondent, Karen Travers. [21:35:00] KAREN TRAVERS, ABC NEWS: Good evening. I am honored to present this year's WHCA Awards to several incredible journalists, some of whom are also wonderful colleagues of mine on the White House beat, journalists who bring the years of wisdom and experience, sharp insights, and tenacious reporting every day to their beats. The Aldo Beckman award for overall excellence in White House coverage is named for a former association president, the late Chicago Tribune Correspondent Aldo Beckman. This year, the award goes to Matt Viser of The Washington Post. The judges said Matt Viser stood out among his competitors for work that went beyond the humdrum of covering the managed events of the presidency and the White House. Viser captured the spirit of Joe Biden, particularly with stories about the President's brother and how his Catholic faith influenced his strategic vision of the office. The WHCA is pleased to give the Aldo Beckman Award to Matt Viser. The WHCA gives out two awards for reporting under deadline pressure, one for print, another for broadcast. This year's print winner is Jeff Mason of Reuters. The judges said, based on a tip and working his sources, Jeff broke the news of a White House solar initiative late on the Sunday night, hours before the administration announced on Monday morning. The speed of just reporting had an impact on the markets and led to multiple other news outlets citing his piece before the official White House announcement the following day. Please welcome the winner of the Deadline Award for Print, from Reuters, Jeff Mason. And now the broadcast award. This year's winner is Phil Mattingly of CNN. The judges said Phil Mattingly of CNN was ahead of the competition and the official White House announcement in breaking the news and the details of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's planned trip to the White House in December 2022. Phil led CNN's coverage of Zelenskyy's visit, including asking both Zelenskyy and President Biden questions at their joint press conference that elicited deeply personal and newsworthy responses. Phil's 16 live shots in a 24-hour period combined scoops, context and depth. Take a look. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Right now, planning is underway for President Zelenskyy to visit the White House to meet with President Biden face to face, a visit that will coincide with the announcement of a new security assistance package, a package that will include some things Zelenskyy has long asked for, Patriot missile systems that White House officials and the Department of Defense have been weighing over the course of the last several weeks and have been moving towards signing off on.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRAVERS
utterances.sentences: We are pleased to honor the deadline reporting of CNN's Phil Mattingly.[21:40:00] The award for excellence in presidential news coverage by visual journalists this year goes to my dear friend, everybody's dear friend, Doug Mills of The New York Times. Of the winning photo, the judges said Doug Mills expertly captured an unscripted moment with President Joe Biden as he emerged from the shadows to celebrate the passage of the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 at an event on the South Lawn. The image is striking for its composition, symmetry, and use of light. The President's expression and posture intensify the atmosphere with a sense of gravity, as you, the gazing marine honor guards, who frame him. Let's congratulate New York Times photographer Doug Mills. The WHCA partners with the University of Florida to present the Collier Prize for State Government Accountability, which is designed to encourage coverage of state government, focusing on investigative and political reporting. For their series about the spectacular failures by the State Bar of California to regulate and enforce the integrity of lawyers in the state, this year, the award goes to Harriet Ryan and Matt Hamilton of the Los Angeles Times. The university said the series showed the bar's failure to prevent a trial attorney from using client settlement money to buy his wife $750,000 diamond earrings, and his mistress, a sitting appellate court justice, a $300,000 beachfront condo. It also showed that disbarment rates for blackmail lawyers are nearly four times more than those of their white peers. Their reporting resulted in reforms, government investigations, increased transparency and new legislation. Please join me in congratulating Harriet Ryan and Matt Hamilton of the Los Angeles Times. The Katharine Graham Award for Courage and Accountability, named in honor of the legendary Washington Post Publisher, goes this year to Josh Gerstein and Alex Ward of POLITICO. The judges said POLITICO's efforts to report, verify and publish the draft Supreme Court opinion reversing abortion rights and the organization's follow-up work exploring the consequences of the decision were globally historic and groundbreaking. It flipped the long-standing belief here in Washington, D.C. that nothing leaks from the Supreme Court. Here was journalism about a ruling that has had a profound and immediate impact on tens of millions of lives. Take a look. (VIDEO PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Please welcome to the microphone, POLITICO White House Correspondent and Playbook Co-Author, Eugene Daniels.

utterances.speaker: EUGENE DANIELS, POLITICO
utterances.sentences: What a beautiful evening. Hello, everyone. Obviously, there are some of us who come to this dinner very excited, to get selfies with celebrities. John Legend, Chrissy Teigen, hello you two. I will come back later. Lisa Vanderpump and Gene Sperling. But, that's not what this is about. What you're really doing here in this ballroom is funding scholarships for the next generation of the fourth estate.Over the last 10 years, the WHCA has given out nearly $1.1 million in scholarships, and leveraged another $1 million in additional aid to aspiring journalists like Julia Benbrook. In 2021, while a student at Northwestern University, she won our Deborah Orin Scholarship. Tonight, she is here as a Washington Correspondent for Spectrum News. Yesterday, we had 28 of this year's scholarship recipients meeting White House Correspondents Weijia Jiang from CBS, Zolan Kanno-Youngs from the New York Times, and Sabrina Siddiqui of The Wall Street Journal. They heard from Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar, a strong supporter of press freedom, and the daughter of a journalist. And they got an on-the-record briefing from Karine Jean-Pierre, sitting in the seats we hope these students will someday occupy. (VIDEO PLAYING) Me and other members of the White House press corps, spent most of yesterday with them, and let me tell you, these scholars are much more impressive than any of us were at that age. These amazing young journalists are here with us tonight. If they come to talk to you, give them a job. Now, with our students, please stand up and let's give them all a round of applause.

utterances.speaker: BILL PLANTE, CBS NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: My name is Bill Plante, and I'd like to show you some of my work.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: For 52 years at CBS News, Bill Plante showed us his work, covering the civil rights struggle.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PLANTE
utterances.sentences: Is this the grand climax?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Vietnam War.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PLANTE
utterances.sentences: Bill Plante, CBS News, (inaudible).(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And Presidents Reagan, Clinton, Bush and Obama.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PLANTE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, do you believe Osama bin Laden's denial that he had anything to do with this?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bill's approach was simple, ask direct questions, and keep your opinion out of it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PLANTE
utterances.sentences: Did you make a mistake in sending arms to Tehran, sir? REAGAN(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: His baritone in case to the best of accountability, journalism, from his front row seat to history, even when getting to that seat required a climb.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CLINTON
utterances.sentences: It was very impressive.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Or when he wasn't in it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: Real point. No. Bill is not here. That's shocking.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The Bill was beloved around the halls of CBS News, collaborative, generous in spirit, and with spirits. On the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday --(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PLANTE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, why is there such a disparity in the way blacks and whites see race relations?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Bill conducted his final presidential interview, steps from the Edmund Pettus Bridge, a place where he'd witnessed the march to Montgomery a half a century earlier, at a time when a black president seemed impossible.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: A white newsman, Bill Plante, who covered the marches then and who is with us here today, quipped that the growing number of white people lowered the quality of the singing.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GWEN IFILL, WASHINGTON WEEK, PBS NEWSHOUR
utterances.sentences: I came to work as an intern and found a racial slur directed at me at my new -- my workspace, and instead of getting assaulted and suing, I just hung in there.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And we're lucky she did. Her talent took her to the Baltimore Evening Sun, Washington Post, and New York Times, where she covered the Clinton White House.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: IFILL
utterances.sentences: How do you address those two things?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: From NBC News.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Then, television came calling. First, NBC.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: IFILL
utterances.sentences: Bob Doll really does have a good argument to make about how his tax cut will help women.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Then in 1999, to the PBS NewsHour and Washington Week. She became the first black woman moderator of a national public affairs show. Gwen was also admired for incisive questions and thorough preparation, skills she brought to the PBS NewsHour anchor desk as one half of the first all-female network news team.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JUDY WOODRUFF, ANCHOR, CBS NEWSHOUR
utterances.sentences: Good evening. I'm Judy Woodruff.

utterances.speaker: IFILL
utterances.sentences: And I'm Gwen Ifill.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She moderated a pair of vice presidential debates and tangled with presidents too.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: OBAMA
utterances.sentences: I always appreciated Gwen's reporting even when I was at the receiving end of one of her tough and thorough interviews.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In a city so often defined by cold power and its abuse, Gwen Ifill shared what she had achieved, turning her smile to light the way for those she could help. She was often a first, but she made sure she wasn't the only.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: IFILL
utterances.sentences: Promise to care about more than yourself to affect the lives of those around you.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tonight we honor Bill Plante and Gwen Ifill posthumously with the Dunnigan-Payne Prize for Lifetime Career Achievement.
